metadata.title: Vacuum brazing of C/C composite to TC4 alloy using nano-Al2O3 strengthened AgCuTi composite filler

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials and Design
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /matdes
Vacuum brazing of C/C composite to TC4 alloy using nano-Al2O3 strengthened AgCuTi composite filler
Y.H. Zhou a, D. Liu a,⁎, H.W. Niu b, X.G. Song a, X.D. Yang a, J.C. Feng a,c a Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Special Welding Technology, Harbin Institute of Technology at Weihai, Weihai 264209, China b Institute of Materials, Changchun University of Technology, Changchun 130012, China c State Key Laboratory of Advanced Welding and Joining, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: liuduo0376@163.com (D. Liu).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.matdes.2015.12.143 0264-1275/© 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 22 September 2015 Received in revised form 7 December 2015 Accepted 23 December 2015 Available online 24 December 2015
Vacuum brazing of C/C composite to TC4 alloy was performed using nano-Al2O3 strengthened AgCuTi composite filler. The microstructure and main properties of the composite filler were characterized. The typical interfacial microstructure of brazed joint is TC4/diffusion layer/Ti–Cu intermetallic layers/Ag(s,s) + Cu(s,s) + TiCu/TiC/C/ C composite. The effects of brazing temperature and addition of nano-Al2O3 on microstructure of brazed joints were investigated by SEM, EDS, TEMandXRD. The diffusion layer, Ti–Cu intermetallic layers and TiC layer thicken with the increasing temperature while the thickness of brazing seam decreases. The TiCu phase in brazing seam excessively develops and almost replaces the Ag(s,s) and Cu(s,s) when brazing temperature reaches 920 °C. The addition of nano-Al2O3 improves the performance of brazed joints by inhibiting the growth of Ti–Cu layers adjacent to TC4 side and offering dispersive nucleation sites for TiCu phase in brazing seam. The joint brazed at 880 °C for 10 min exhibits the highest shear strength of 27.8 MPa. The fracture positions of brazed joints are also discussed in this paper.
© 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Keywords: C/C composite TC4 alloy Brazing Composite filler Interfacial microstructure Fracture positions

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
C/C composites are extensively applied in aviation, aerospace and electronic fields due to their outstanding physical andmechanical properties such as low density, high-thermal shock and fatigue resistance, especially their excellent mechanical properties at high temperature [1–3]. Ti–6Al–4V alloy is one of the most promising alternative lightweight alloy. It has also been widely used in navigation, marine engineering and automobile manufacturing [4–6]. Therefore, it is necessary to join C/C composite to Ti–6Al–4V alloy in order to further utilize their excellent properties. For example, as part of a proposed nozzle component, the C/C composite/Ti–6Al–4V brazed joints can greatly decrease the weight and increase the efficiency of rocket engine [7]. However, it is a great challenge to join C/C composite with Ti–6Al–4V alloy because of the large difference in coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) and other thermo-physical properties.
A variety of methods have been developed to realize the joining of C/C composites to metals such as brazing, adhesive bonding as well as partial transient liquid phase bonding [8–11]. Especially, brazing is considered as a proper method for bonding dissimilar materials. The
addition of filler metal and relative low bonding temperature can effectively decrease the residual stress of brazed joints [12–17]. Yuanxun Shen et al. [12] joinedC/C composite to aNi-based alloy usingAgCufiller alloy with an alumina ceramic interlayer. A Ti film of 10 μm thick was deposited on the joining surface of C/C composite by a magnetron sputteringmethod before brazing. The Al2O3 interlayer acted as a barrier to the diffusion and reaction of Ni and Ti which in turn improved the joint strength due to the reduced residual stress. Toshitaka Lkeshoji et al. [13] studied the brazing of C/C composite to Ni-based alloys with AgCuTi and Fe-based filler alloy. In recent years, AgCuTi system alloys have been regarded as a promising filler for brazing of C/C composite to Ti–6Al–4V alloy [15,16]. Their advantages include favorable wettability and superior mechanical properties compared with other filler alloys. However, the relief of residual stress in the joint is limited in case of brazing C/C composites tometals. It is imperative to alleviate residual stress and improve joining properties. Therefore, composite fillers were developed by bring in fibers or tiny ceramic particles with lower CTE into traditional brazing fillers. The mismatch in CTE between substrates and brazing seam can be reduced [18–20]. However, less previous studies have been reported on brazing of C/C composite to Ti–6Al–4V alloy using composite fillers. Therefore, nano-Al2O3 particles strengthened AgCuTi composite filler was employed in this paper to further decrease residual stress and improve the properties of brazed joint.
In this study, nano-Al2O3 particles reinforced AgCuTi compositefiller (abbreviated as AgCuTip filler) was developed to braze C/C composite and Ti–6Al–4V alloy. The effect of brazing temperature and addition of nano-Al2O3 on microstructure of brazed joints were studied. Furthermore, the mechanical properties and fracture positions of brazed joints were also investigated.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental procedures
sections.text:
The base materials are 3D C/C composite and Ti–6Al–4V alloy (for the convenience, Ti–6Al–4V alloy ismarked as TC4 alloy in the following figures). The C/C composite is a kind of carbon matrix composite reinforced by carbon fiber. The matrix of C/C composite is pyrolytic carbon which is fabricated by chemical vapor infiltration (CVI) process. The main properties of the base materials and filler are list in Table 1. The C/C composite was cut into blocks with a dimension of 5 mm × 5 mm × 5 mm by spark cutting. Before brazing, the TC4 alloy was cut into two dimensions, namely, 20 mm × 10 mm × 3 mm and 10 mm × 10 mm × 3 mm. Two dimensions of specimens are all used for brazing, and after brazing, the brazed specimen with a dimension of 20 mm × 10 mm × 3 mm is proper for shear strength test while the brazed specimenwith a dimension of 10mm× 10mm× 3mm is proper formetallographic observation. Nano-Al2O3 particles with a diameter of 20 nmandmicron-Ti particleswere added into AgCu eutectic powder (Ag–26.7Cu), and then themixturewasmilled for eight hours byusing a QM-SB planetary ballmill to prepare AgCuTipfiller. The content of nanoAl2O3 and micron-Ti in AgCuTip is 0.3 wt.% and 4.5 wt.%, respectively. The microstructures of C/C composite and TC4 are shown in Fig. 1. Before joining, the brazing surfaces of the C/C composites and TC4 alloys were ground on SiC grit papers and then polished usingdiamondpastes. Finally, all of the polished specimenswere ultrasonically cleaned in ethanol for 10min and dried by air blowing. Then, the AgCuTip powderwas spread on the surface of TC4 alloy. As depicted in Fig. 2(a), this method could guarantee the powder thickness of 50 μm. Subsequently, the
prepared specimens were assembled into a sandwich type as shown in Fig. 2(b), and then placed into the vacuum furnace carefully.
The brazing was performed in a vacuum furnace of less than 3.0 × 10−3 Pa. During brazing, each specimen was first heated to 800 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min and held for approximately 10 min. Subsequently, the brazing specimens were heated to brazing temperature at a heating rate of 5 °C/min and held at brazing temperature for 10 min. The brazing temperature adopted in this study is 860, 880, 900 and 920 °C. The brazed joints were then cooled down to 300 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min. Finally, the joints were spontaneously cooled down to room temperature in furnace.
The cross-sections of the brazed joints were cut and prepared for metallographic analysis. The microstructures of the joints were characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). Furthermore, the microstructure of C/C composite side and TC4 side was investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) in order to identify the interfacial phases accurately. The brazed specimens for XRD analysis were prepared by spark cutting. Then, the prepared specimens were polished layer by layer along the direction parallel to the brazing seam. Therefore, the XRD analysis can be executed on the surface of C/C composite side and TC4 side, respectively. Moreover, transmission electron microscopy characterization (TEM, JEM-2100, JEOL, Japan) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) analyses were executed to investigate the effect of
ials: (a) C/C composite; (b) TC4.
nano-Al2O3 particles. Samples for TEM investigation were prepared using ion milling system (PIPS, Model 695 Gatan, USA). The room temperature shear strength of brazed joints wasmeasured by universalmaterial machine of type Instron 1186 at a constant speed of 1 mm/min, and the schematic diagram of shear test is shown in Fig. 2(c). For each set of experimental data, at least five specimens were tested to obtain the average shear strength of brazed joints. After shear test, the fracture surfaces were characterized by SEM and EDS to investigate the fracture positions.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1. Characterization of AgCu and AgCuTip filler
The morphologies of original AgCu eutectic filler and AgCuTip filler are shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3(a) shows a large number of AgCu eutecticfiller balls in the filler. The tiny AgCu balls with average diameters of 60 μm have smooth surfaces. Comparedwith themorphologies of AgCu eutectic filler, the microscopic morphology of AgCuTip filler exhibits rougher surfaces and the size of filler balls increases slightly as shown in Fig. 3(b). Furthermore, some plate-like filler is formed during the ball milling process (Fig. 3b). These changes can be explained by the squeezing and colliding between filler balls.
To demonstrate whether metallurgical reactions occurred during ball milling process, X-ray diffraction analysis was performed. The XRD patterns of AgCu eutectic filler and AgCuTip composite filler are shown in Fig. 4(a) and (b), respectively. The peaks of element Ag and Cu can be detected both in the AgCu eutectic filler and AgCuTip composite filler. Because the content of nano-Al2O3 is rather less in AgCuTip filler, therefore, the peaks of nano-Al2O3 can hardly be indexed in the profile. Moreover, no additional peaks of other phases have been found except element Ti in Fig. 4(b), which demonstrates that no metallurgical reaction occurred during ball milling process.
Based on the theory of Eshelby and law of hybrid composites, the CTE and Young's modulus of AgCuTip filler can be calculated according to the following formulas (1) and (2) respectively [21].
αC ¼ αM− 3fEI αM−αIð ÞEI−EMð Þ 1þ 2fð Þ þ 3EM ð1Þ
whereαC is the CTE of the composite filler, f is the volume percentage of nano-Al2O3 in composite filler, αM and αI are the CTE of AgCuTi filler and nano-Al2O3 particles respectively, while EM and EI are the Young's modulus of AgCuTi filler and nano-Al2O3 particles respectively.
EC ¼ EM 1− 3f EI−EMð ÞEI−EMð Þ 1þ 2fð Þ þ 3EM −1 ð2Þ
where EC is the Young's modulus of the composite filler. According to the parameters shown in Table 1, the volume percentage of nanoAl2O3 in composite filler (f) is about 3.66%. Therefore, the CTE and Young's modulus of the composite filler (αC, EC) is about 17.4 × 10−6 K−1 and99.3 GPa, respectively. It demonstrates that the addition of nano-Al2O3 can reduce the CTE and increase the Young's modulus of the AgCuTi filler.

sections.heading: 3.2. Typical interfacial microstructure of the C/C composite/AgCuTip/TC4 joints
sections.text:
The backscattered electron images of C/C composite/AgCuTip/TC4 joint brazed at 880 °C for 10 min are shown in Fig. 5. The joint consists of one diffusion layer and three reaction layers, as shown in Fig. 5(a): zone I (diffusion layer adjacent to TC4 alloy), zone II (reaction zone adjacent to diffusion layer), zone III (brazing seam) and zone IV (continuous thin reaction layer adjacent to C/C composite).
Fig. 5(a) shows a typical microstructure of the joint brazed at 880 °C for 10 min. The joint exhibits sound bonding without any cavities or cracks in brazing seam. A diffusion layer (layer A) near TC4 side was formed during brazing process. Fig. 5(b) and (c) show the magnified microstructures of TC4/AgCuTip interface and AgCuTip/C/C composite
interface, respectively. It can be seen that there exist three reaction layers (layer B, C and D) near TC4 side and one thin layer (layer H) near C/C composite side. In the center of brazing zone, there are three different phases: white matrix phase (marked by E), gray phase (marked by F) and dark blocky phase (marked by G).
In order to further investigate the interfacial microstructure, EDS analysis was performed and the results are shown in Table 2. According to the elemental contents and Ti–Cu binary alloy phase diagram [22], the three reaction layers in zone II are probably Ti2Cu (layer B), TiCu (layer C) and Ti3Cu4 intermetallic phase (layer D). Furthermore, the content of element Ti decreases from A to D while the content of element Cu has the reverse tendency. This indicates that diffusion and reactions occur between base material and brazing filler. In the center of brazing zone, the white phase (marked by E) is Ag-based solid solution (abbreviated as Ag(s,s)) while the dark phase (marked by G) and gray phase (marked by F) are TiCu and Cu-based solid solution (abbreviated as Cu(s,s)), respectively.Moreover, the content of element C in layer H is higher than that in other layers. One reason is that layer H is very thin,
the results of EDS contain element C from C/C composite. The other reason is that reactionmight occur near C/C composite side and new phase was formed. Therefore, layer H is probably TiC reaction layer according to the analysis above.
To further identify the phase constitutions, XRD analysis was performed, and the results are shown in Fig. 6. Fig. 6(a) shows the XRD pattern of reaction layers near C/C composite side. The peaks of TiC phase could be indexed in the profile. The formation of TiC reaction layer is relevant to the reaction between element Ti and C/C composite, and the possible reaction can be expressed as follows [23]:
Tiþ C→TiC ΔG kJ mol−1 ¼ −186þ 0:01T: ð3Þ
The Gibbs free energy of forming TiC calculated by formula (3) is about −174 kJ mol−1 at 880 °C. The Gibbs free energies of formation TiC is negative. Therefore, element Ti and C can react with each other at 880 °C. In fact, during brazing process, the AgCu eutectic melt firstly, and then the element Ti can dissolve in it. The dissolved Ti diffused toward C/C composite, and finally reacted with element C to form TiC reaction layer. The formation of TiC promotes the wetting of brazing filler on C/C composite, which is in accordance with literatures reported by other researchers on brazing carbon materials using titaniferous fillers [24–28]. Fig. 6(b) shows the XRD pattern of reaction layers near TC4 side. The peaks of Ti2Cu and Ti3Cu4 phases can only be indexed in Fig. 6(b). It is indicated that Ti2Cu and Ti3Cu4 phases are only formed near TC4 side. This is consistent with the result estimated by EDS measurement. As analyzed above, the typical interfacial microstructure of brazed joint is TC4/diffusion layer/Ti2Cu + TiCu + Ti3Cu4/ Ag(s,s) + Cu(s,s) + TiCu/TiC/C/C composite.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of brazing temperature and addition of nano-Al2O3 on the interfacial microstructure of C/C composite/AgCuTip/TC4 joints
sections.text:
Fig. 7 demonstrates the interfacial microstructure of C/C composite/ AgCuTip/TC4 joints brazed at different temperatures for 10 min. It is revealed that the interfacialmicrostructure has significantly changedwith the increase of brazing temperature from860 °C to 920 °C. The thickness of diffusion layer is only 5 μm at 860 °C and increases to approximate 20 μm as the brazing temperature reaches 920 °C. This is due to the intensive diffusion and dissolution between brazing filler and TC4 alloy at high temperature. On the contrary, because of the effect of capillarity at high temperature, the molten filler is expelled out of the joint gap. Therefore, the width of brazing seam decreases with the increasing
temperature. On the other hand, Ti2Cu and TiCu layers close to TC4 side thicken graduallywith the increasing brazing temperature. However, Ti3Cu4 layer firstly thickens when the brazing temperature is below 900 °C and decreases significantly when the temperature exceeds 900 °C as shown in Fig. 7(d). It can be attributed to the excessive growth of TiCu phase in the brazing seam which depletes element Ti and Cu. Therefore, Ti3Cu4 layer almost disappears when the temperature reaches 920 °C. To investigate the effect of temperature on TiC intermetallic layer, high magnified SEM image of TiC layer was obtained (the inserted images in Fig. 7). The TiC layer is thin and discrete at lower brazing temperature (860 °C). Continuous TiC layer can be found when brazed at 880 °C and the thickness of this layer is desirable. However, further increasing the brazing temperature to 900 °C and 920 °C, as
rent temperatures for 10 min: (a) 860 °C, (b) 880 °C, (c) 900 °C and (d) 920 °C.
shown in Fig. 7(c) and (d), leads to the formation of massive TiC layer which deteriorates the property of brazed joints.
With the increase of temperature from 860 °C to 920 °C, the microstructure of brazing seam also changes obviously. At lower temperature (860 °C), the brazing seammainly consists of blocky Cu(s,s), Ag(s,s) and few black TiCu phase. Favorable microstructure can be achieved at 880 °C. Compared to the microstructure brazed at 860 °C, more TiCu phase can be found in brazing seam, and the microstructure has been
refined. However, the number of Ag matrix reduces and some TiCu phase becomes coarsewhen brazed at 900 °C. It is noted that themicrostructure has significantly changed when the temperature increases to 920 °C. The Cu(s,s) and Ag(s,s) are almost replaced by the massive TiCu phase because of the effect of high temperature.
To investigate the effect of nano-Al2O3 addition in AgCuTip filler on the microstructure of brazed joints, the experiment using AgCuTi filler was carried out at 860 °C for 10min. Fig. 8(a) and (b) display themicrostructure of the joints brazed with AgCuTi and AgCuTip, respectively. It can be clearly seen that the structure of C/C composite/AgCuTi/TC4 joint is similar with that of C/C composite/AgCuTip/TC4. However, compared Fig. 8(a) with Fig. 8(b), some difference can be easily observed. The average thickness of Ti–Cu intermetallic layers near the TC4 side decreases from 10 μm to 5 μm. This indicates that the addition of nanoAl2O3 can restrain the growth of Ti–Cu phases close to TC4 side. This phenomenon can be explained by surface adsorption theory [29]. Generally speaking, the crystal plane with the maximum surface tension grows comparatively faster. Meanwhile, most of the surface-active substance can be easily absorbed by the crystal plane. The interfacial energy declines with the increase of the amount of adsorbed substance. Therefore, the growth rate of crystal plane would be decreased. It is well known that nanoparticles are unstable surface-active substance due to its relatively high specific surface area and high surface tension. Comparedwith Ti–Cu particles, the nano-Al2O3 particles possess higher specific surface area and higher surface tension. Therefore, the adsorption of nano-Al2O3 particles on the Ti–Cu surface can easily occurred, and the growth of Ti–Cu phases can be inhibited. Moreover, the brazing seam of C/C composite/AgCuTi/TC4 joint mainly consists of Ag(s,s) and some blocky Cu(s,s). However, the microstructure becomes refined and the trivial black TiCu phase is dispersively distributed in the brazing seam when the AgCuTip filler is used.
In order to further investigate the effect of nano-Al2O3 particles in brazing seam, the TEM observation and selected area electron diffraction pattern are illustrated in Fig. 8(c) and (d), respectively. Some spherical particles with a diameter of about 20 nm can be observed in Fig. 8(c). These particles was conformed as Al2O3 by SAED (PDF# 46- 1212), which indicated that the nano-Al2O3 particles didn't react with
other substance during brazing process. It is reported that the addition of nano-particles can reduce the degree of undercooling of composite filler [30]. Based on the theory of solidification, the nano-Al2O3 particles acted as heterogeneous nucleation sites can promote the nucleation of TiCu phases under lower degree of undercooling. Furthermore, the CTE of TiCu phase in brazing seamcan be calculated according to the following formula (4) [31]:
α ¼ αTiVf þ 1−Vfð ÞαCu ð4Þ
where α is the CTE of TiCu phase in brazing seam, and Vf is the volume fraction of titanium in TiCu phase. Therefore, the calculated CTE of TiCu phase is about 12.6 × 10−6 k−1. The TiCu phase with lower CTE
decreases themismatch of CTE among C/C composite, brazing seam and TC4 alloy, and therefore improve the property of the brazed joint.
In conclusion, the effect of nano-Al2O3 addition in AgCuTi filler can be summarized into two points. On one hand, the nano-Al2O3might impede the diffusion of Cu to TC4 side and suppress the growth of Ti–Cu intermetallic layers. On the other hand, nano-Al2O3 can serve as heterogeneous nucleation sites of TiCu phase. Therefore, nano-Al2O3 promotes the formation of TiCu phase in brazing seam.

sections.heading: 3.4. Mechanical property evaluation of the C/C composite/AgCuTip/TC4 joint
sections.text:
To assess the mechanical property of brazed joints, shear strength tests were performed at room temperature. Fig. 9 shows the effect of brazing temperatures on shear strength of brazed joints. It can be observed that the shear strength of specimens brazed at 860 °C is insufficient (less than 20 MPa). This can ascribe to the insufficient atomic diffusion and reactions betweenfiller and basematerials. Themaximum average shear strength can reach 27.8 MPa when brazed at 880 °C for 10 min, which is higher than most of the C/C composite/TC4 brazed joints reported by other researches [7,18,32]. However, the shear strength remarkably decreases with a further increase in brazing temperature. This can be attributed to the excessive diffusion and reactions between filler and base materials. Therefore, the reaction layers such as Ti–Cu layers close to TC4 side and TiC layer excessively develop.
The fracture analysis was performed by SEM and EDS to investigate the fracture positions of brazed joints. Fig. 10(a) and (b) show the macro-fracture surfaces of the joint brazed at lower temperature (860 °C). It can be seen that the fracture locations are mainly occurred
in two regions as marked by I and II. Zone I is the fracture surface where the axes of carbon fibers are parallel to junction surface. In zone II, the axes of carbon fibers are perpendicular to junction surface. The magnified SEM images of zone I (Fig. 11(a) and (b)) show that zone I mainly consists of parallel carbon fibers. This indicates that the fracture occurs in C/C composite when the axes of carbon fibers are parallel to junction surface. The magnified images of zone II are shown in Fig. 11(c) and (d). It can be seen that some axes of carbon fibers are covered with intermetallic layer. Coupled with the analysis of EDS results (Table 3), the intermetallic layer is confirmed as TiC layer adjacent to C/C composite. This indicates that the fracture mainly occurs in TiC layer.
Fig. 12(a) and (b) show the macro-fracture surfaces of the joint brazed at proper temperature (880 °C). It can be observed that the fracture surfaces of TC4 side and C/C composite side both consist of carbon fibers. The fracture occurs in C/C composite entirely. It is indicated that a desirable brazed joint can be achieved at 880 °C for 10 min. This is also consistent with the results of shear strength tests.
Fig. 13 shows the macro-fracture surfaces of the joint brazed at higher temperature (920 °C). It can be observed that the fracturemainly occurs in two zones asmarked by i and ii. As stated above, zone i mainly consists of parallel carbon fibers. To investigate the fracture position of zone ii, the magnified SEM images of zones A, B and C are shown in Fig. 14(a), (b) and (c), respectively. The EDS results taken from the testing positions denoted in Fig. 14 are summarized in Table 4. Coupled with the EDS results of point D and point E, we can conclude that the fracture partially occurs in TiC layer when the axes of carbon fibers are perpendicular to junction surface. Moreover, according to the EDS
C, t = 10 min): (a) TC4 side and (b) C/C composite side.
results of point F, the fracture of zone C probably occurs in brazing seam, because Ag(s,s) and TiCu phase are detected in this area. The microstructure characteristic explains the reason why the fracture partially occurs in the TiC layer and partially occurs in brazing seamwhen brazed at 920 °C.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Brazing of C/C composite to TC4 alloy was performed at 860, 880, 900 as well as 920 °C by using nano-Al2O3 strengthened AgCuTi composite filler. The effects of brazing temperature and addition of nanoAl2O3 on the microstructure and mechanical property of brazed joints are investigated. Major conclusions are summarized as follows:
(1) No metallurgical reaction occurs between AgCu eutectic powder and micron-Ti particles during ball milling process. Compared with AgCu eutectic powder, the microscopic morphology of AgCuTip filler exhibits plate-like and rougher surfaces and the size of filler balls increases slightly after ball milling process. The addition of nano-Al2O3 can reduce the CTE and increase the Young's modulus of AgCuTi filler. (2) The typical interfacial microstructure of the brazed joint is TC4/ diffusion layer/Ti2Cu + TiCu + Ti3Cu4/ Ag(s,s) + Cu(s,s) + TiCu/TiC/C/C composite.
(3) The diffusion layer, Ti–Cu intermetallic layers and TiC layer thicken with the increasing temperature while the thickness of brazing seam decreases. The TiCu phase in brazing seam excessively develops and replaces Ag(s,s) and Cu(s,s) when brazing temperature reaches 920 °C. The addition of nano-Al2O3 improves the performance of brazed joints by inhibiting the growth of Ti–Cu layers close to TC4 side and offering dispersive nucleation sites for TiCu phase in brazing seam. (4) The maximum shear strength of the joint is 27.8 MPa brazed at 880 °C for 10 min. The fracture position is related to the orientation of carbon fiber. The joints are fractured in C/C composites when the axes of carbon fibers are parallel to junction surface. Moreover, when the axes of carbon fibers are perpendicular to junction surface, the fracture mainly occurs at TiC layer at low brazing temperature, while the fracture occurs at TiC layer and brazing seam at high brazing temperature. The joints are fractured at C/C composite entirelywhen brazed at 880 °C for 10min.

sections.text: We are grateful for the financial support to this study from National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant Nos. 51505105, 51405099) and Natural Science Foundation of Shandong Province (Grant No. ZR2014EEQ001).

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 22 September 2015 Received in revised form 7 December 2015 Accepted 23 December 2015 Available online 24 December 2015 Vacuum brazing of C/C composite to TC4 alloy was performed using nano-Al2O3 strengthened AgCuTi composite filler. The microstructure and main properties of the composite filler were characterized. The typical interfacial microstructure of brazed joint is TC4/diffusion layer/Ti–Cu intermetallic layers/Ag(s,s) + Cu(s,s) + TiCu/TiC/C/ C composite. The effects of brazing temperature and addition of nano-Al2O3 on microstructure of brazed joints were investigated by SEM, EDS, TEMandXRD. The diffusion layer, Ti–Cu intermetallic layers and TiC layer thicken with the increasing temperature while the thickness of brazing seam decreases. The TiCu phase in brazing seam excessively develops and almost replaces the Ag(s,s) and Cu(s,s) when brazing temperature reaches 920 °C. The addition of nano-Al2O3 improves the performance of brazed joints by inhibiting the growth of Ti–Cu layers adjacent to TC4 side and offering dispersive nucleation sites for TiCu phase in brazing seam. The joint brazed at 880 °C for 10 min exhibits the highest shear strength of 27.8 MPa. The fracture positions of brazed joints are also discussed in this paper. © 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
